In situ functionalized sulfonic copolymer toward recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for efficient Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime Difan Li Dan Mao Jing Li Yu Zhou ⁎ Jun Wang ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 210009, P. R. China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering College of Chemical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 210009 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel: +86 25 83172264; fax: +86 25 83172261. Graphical abstract Exploring environmentally friendly, efficient and recyclable heterogeneous catalysts for low-temperature liquid-phase organic reactions are important for the development of green and sustainable processes. In this work, we applied an in situ sulfonated polymeric solid acid H-PDVB-SO3H for catalyzing liquid-phase Beckmann rearrangements for the first time, with post-sulfonated sample and other various counterparts as control catalysts. H-PDVB-SO3H was prepared by copolymerization of divinylbenzene with sodium p-styrene sulfonate under solvothermal condition, followed by ion-exchanging to convert the polymer into proton form. It possessed a large surface area, plenty of mesopores and high sulfur content, and exhibited the high yield to ε-caprolactam (75%) with quite steady reusability in the heterogeneous Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime. The catalyst also showed good substrate compatibility with such a high reaction rate that the reaction time was as short as 1h. No any co-catalysts or metals were used in the catalytic system, making the catalyst an environmentally friendly and efficient candidate for Beckmann rearrangements. Keywords Mesoporous materials Heterogeneous catalysis Beckmann rearrangement Solid acids Polymer catalysts 1 Introduction Transformation from ketoximes to corresponding amides through Beckmann rearrangements produces various vital synthetic intermediates and raw materials for medicines, agrochemicals, fragrances and polymers. Among them, the most important industrial application is the produce of ε-caprolactam, the starting material for manufacturing nylon fibres and resins [1]. The liquid acids such as concentrated sulfuric acid or oleum are homogeneous catalysts for the commercial process for producing ε-caprolactam, in which ammonia is used to neutralize the product mixture. This process leads to severely ecological concerns and economical drawbacks, such as the inevitable equipment corrosion, difficulty in product separation, and formation of large amount low value-added ammonium sulphates [2,3]. In order to overcome these problems, solid catalysts have been attempted for this reaction in vapour process, including MCM-41 [4], silicalite-1 [5], WOx/Bi-SBA-15 [6,7], TS-1 [8], metal pillared-ilerite [9] and so forth. The vapour-phase process is highly energy-consuming because it is usually conducted above 300°C [10–13], and often leads to low selectivity of lactams and fast catalyst deactivation arising from coke formation [4,5]. Moreover, it is difficult to produce some important lactams, such as ω-laurolactam, in the gas phase due to the instability of the precursors [14]. Therefore, the liquid-phase Beckmann rearrangement has attracted growing attentions; yet, it is still one challenge to explore green and recyclable heterogeneous catalyst under mild conditions. Many efforts have been made towards liquid-phase Beckmann rearrangement. Various organocatalysts were used for rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime, such as cyclonic chloride [15], 1-chloro-2,3-diphenylcyclopropenium ion [16], bis(2-oxo-3-oxazolidinyl) phosphinic chloride (BOP-Cl) [17], TsCl [18], trifluoroacetic acid [19] and so on. They exhibited good yields to ε-caprolactam at relatively low temperatures, but most of them involved environmentally unfriendly halogen with difficulty in catalyst isolation. Task-specific ionic liquids (ILs) tethered with acidic group [20,21] caused liquid–liquid biphasic or homogeneous systems, but excessive IL amount relative to the substrate was needed; in this case, recycling of IL catalyst was not as convenient as a heterogeneous catalyst. In order to improve the catalyst separation and recycling, various solid catalysts were used in the low-temperature liquid-phase rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime, including H-Beta [22], tungstated zirconia [23], and sulfonated mesoporous silica [24]. However, the catalytic reusability data of those catalysts were not shown in those literatures. There have been a few of studies that reported the reusability of solid catalysts, which showed some limitations in catalytic activities. For examples, Al-MCM-41 presented well reusability for rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime, but showed a low conversion of 50.6% [25]. Titanium-exchanged montmorillonite demonstrated well catalytic conversion (96%) and selectivity (74%) for rearranging cyclododecanone oxime, but required very long reaction time (20h) [26]. Cs salt of phosphotungstic acid was a recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime, which however needed the high temperature (150°C) and long time (6h) to reach the moderate conversion (80.8%) [27]. Heteropolyanion-based ILs materials demonstrated high activity for the rearrangement of various ketoximes; nevertheless, a co-catalyst such as ZnCl2 was indispensible and a sluggish deactivation was observed in recycling tests [28,29]. Sulfonic acid group (SO3H) functionalized polymer materials have been developed as effective catalysts for many acid-catalyzed reactions [30–32]. As the typical commercial strong acidic cation exchange resin, Amberlyst-15 has a small surface area and low thermal stability, which limits its practical application in catalysis. For Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime, mesoporous polymers functionalized with SO3H have been designed and used as heterogeneous catalysts. For example, meso-structured polymers FDU-14-SO3H demonstrated the conversion of 91.4% and selectivity of 85.8% (yield 78.4%) for liquid-phase Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime, and could be reused for several times with slight decrease of conversion [31]. Hypercrosslinked organic polymer HBS-4 [33] showed the high yield of 83.4% to ε-caprolactam with the reaction time of 6h and its reusability was unclear. Generally, these polymeric solid acids avoid the utilization of any metals that may leach in catalytic systems, thus being ecologically sustainable and noncorrosive. However, only post-sulfonated polymers were tested in the Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime and no study is related to their substrate compatibility. In this paper, sulfonic group is in situ incorporated into polymeric skeleton, giving a non-post-sulfonated polymer material (H-PDVB-SO3H) that is used as a heterogeneous solid acid catalyst for liquid-phase Beckmann rearrangements for the first time. H-PDVB-SO3H with large surface area and high content of the sulfonic group is prepared through copolymerization of divinylbenzene (DVB) and sodium p-styrene sulfonate, followed by an ion-exchange. Optimization of reaction conditions, catalytic reusability, and comparison with various control catalysts are systematically investigated. The catalyst is also assessed in the rearrangement of various other ketoximes to evaluate the substrate compatibility. The results show that H-PDVB-SO3H is highly active in transforming aromatic oximes, especially cyclohexanone oxime, to the corresponding amides. The advantages of this heterogeneous catalysis system include the very short reaction time of 1h, easy recovery and steady reuse of the solid acid catalyst, and no need of any co-catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Cyclohexanone oxime (98wt.%), 2,2-azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30wt.%), sodium acetate trihydrate (CH3COONa, 99wt.%), tetrahydrofuran (THF, 99wt.%) and hydroxylamine hydrochloride (NH2OH·HCl, 98.5wt.%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Sodium p-styrene sulfonate (90wt.%), divinylbenzene (DVB, 80wt.%) and styrene (ST, 99wt.%) were provided by Aladdin Chem. Co., Ltd. Acetophenone (98wt.%), concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 98wt.%) and chlorosulfonic acid (ClSO3H) were supplied by Shanghai Lingfeng Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Acetophenone oxime (98wt.%), benzophenone oxime (97wt.%) and cyclopentanone oxime (97wt.%) were acquired from Tianjin Heowns Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Sulfonic acid group-functionalized polymer H-PDVB-SO3H was prepared through two steps (Scheme 1 ) according to the Ref. [34]. In the first step, H-PDVB-SO3Na was synthesized from copolymerization of DVB and sodium p-styrene sulfonate under solvothermal condition. In detail, 2.0g of DVB was added into a solution containing 0.05g of AIBN and 20mL of THF, followed by addition of 2.0mL of water and 3.17g of sodium p-styrene sulfonate. After stirring at room temperature for 3h, the mixture was solvothermally treated at 100°C for 24h. The solvent in the product mixture was evaporated slowly at room temperature, washed successively with water, ethanol and diethyl ether, and dried at 80°C for 12h to give the product H-PDVB-SO3Na. In the secondary step, H-PDVB-SO3Na compound was further treated by using 1M (molL−1) sulfuric acid, giving the sample H-PDVB-SO3H. In a typical run, 1.0g of H-PDVB-SO3Na was dispersed in 10mL ethanol, and then 5g sulfuric acid (1M) was added dropwise. After stirring for 24h at room temperature, the solid was obtained by filtration, washed with water until the filtrate was neutral, and then dried at 80°C for 12h. (Elemental analysis Calcd: C 65.09wt.%; H 6.06wt.%; S 8.19wt.%.) For comparison, two other control solid acids, post-sulfonated mesoporous polymer (P(DVB-ST)SO3H), sulfonic acid-modified mesoporous silica SBA-15 (SBA-15-SO3H) were prepared according to the previous literatures (details are in Supporting Information) [35]. 2.3 Characterization Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was recorded on a Nicolet iS10 FT-IR instrument (KBr discs) in the 4000–400cm−1 region. Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites of the typical sample were measured by the pyridine adsorption FT-IR spectrum [36]. Thermogravimetry (TG) analysis was carried out with a STA409 instrument in dry air at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were performed on a HITACHI S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope. Nitrogen (N2) adsorption isotherms and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas were measured at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (−196°C) by using a BELSORP-MINI analyzer. The samples were degassed at 120°C for 3h to a vacuum of 10−3 Torr before analysis, and pore size distribution curves were calculated using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model. CHNS elemental analysis was performed on an elemental analyzer Vario EL cube. The acid amount was determined by dispersing catalysts in aqueous solution of NaCl through a typical acid-base titration with NaOH solution. Hydrogen nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) experiments were carried out on a Bruker DPX 300 spectrometer at ambient temperature by using CDCl3 as the solvent and TMS (tetramethylsilane) as an internal reference. 2.4 General procedure for preparation of oximes 4-Methoxyacetophenone oxime, 4-Chloroacetophenone oxime and 4-Nitroacetophenone oxime were synthesized according to the literature [37]. In detail, a mixture of ketone (0.025mol), NH2OH·HCl (0.037mol, 2.54g), CH3COONa (0.0625mol, 5.13g), 20mL ethyl alcohol and 30mL water were placed in a 150mL round-bottomed flask with a reflux condenser. The reaction system became a clear solution, and was heated at 80°C until complete consumption of ketone. After cooling down to room temperature, the precipitate was separated by filtration, thoroughly washed with plenty of water, dried under a vacuum, and finally purified by the recrystallization with ethyl alcohol. 4-Methoxyacetophenone oxime (white solid): 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3, Fig. S1): δ 2.28 (s, 3H), 3.82 (s, 3H),6.92 (d, 2H), 7.58 (d, 2H), 9.30 (s, 1H). 4-Chloroacetophenone oxime (white solid): 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3, Fig. S2): δ 2.28 (s, 3H), 7.36 (d, 2H), 7.54 (d, 2H), 8.52 (s, 1H). 4-Nitroacetophenone oxime (light yellow solid): 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3, Fig. S3): δ 2.32 (s, 3H), 8.12 (d, 2H), 7.83 (s, 1H), 8.25 (d, 2H). 2.5 Catalytic test Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime was carried out in a 25mL round-bottomed flask reactor equipped with a reflux condenser. Typically, the solvent of benzonitrile (PhCN) (5mL), cyclohexanone oxime (1.0mmol) and catalyst (0.1g) were charged into the flask reactor, which was heated at 130°C for 1h under the continuous stirring (750rmin−1). Catalyst amount, reaction temperature, solvent type and amount were varied to investigate the impacts on the reaction conditions. After reaction, the resulting mixture was cooled down and the internal standard n-dodecane was added, then a portion of liquid phase was centrifuged out of the mixture for analysis. Quantitative analysis was conducted using gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a FID detector and a capillary column (SE-30, 50m×0.25mm×0.6μm). Only cyclohexanone derived from the deoximation of cyclohexanone oxime was detected as the by-product besides the major rearrangement product ε-caprolactam. Other possible by-products like cyclohexen-1-one, nitriles and dimers were detected in trace amount. Conversion of cyclohexanone oxime and selectivity to ε-caprolactam were calculated as the following: Con. (%)=(mol ε-caprolactam+mol cyclohexanone)/mol initial cyclohexanone oxime; Sel. (%)=mol ε-caprolactam/(mol ε-caprolactam+mol cyclohexanone). Beckmann rearrangements over other substrates were conducted similarly. In order to test the catalytic recyclability of H-PDVB-SO3H, the catalyst was separated by filtration and washed with ethyl acetate three times after reaction dried in vacuum at 80°C. The recovered catalyst was regenerated by washing with diluted H2SO4 and subsequently water, followed by drying at 80°C. The regenerated catalyst was then charged into the next run for reuse. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of copolymer catalyst H-PDVB-SO3H The sulfonic group-functionalized copolymer H-PDVB-SO3H is prepared by direct free radical copolymerization of sodium p-styrene sulfonate and DVB, followed by acidification with H2SO4 (Scheme 1). Thermal stability of H-PDVB-SO3H is investigated by TG analysis. As shown in Fig. 1 A, the initial decomposition temperature of H-PDVB-SO3H is about 240°C. The slight weight loss at the early heating stage before 150°C is due to the release of moisture and constitutional water, while the drastic weight loss in the range 240–465°C arises from the complete decomposition of sulfonic group. The weight loss at the high temperatures of 470–590°C is assigned to destruction of the polymer network [38]. Moreover, the DSC curve shows strong peaks at around 370°C and 470°C for H-PDVB-SO3H, which is attributable to decomposition temperatures of the sulfonic group and polymer network, respectively. These results reveal well thermal stability for the sulfonic acid group-functionalized polymer H-PDVB-SO3H. Fig. 1B depicts the FT-IR spectra of H-PDVB-SO3H. Remarkably, characteristic vibrations for organic moiety are well detected. The bands at around 1600cm−1 and 1449cm−1 are due to CC skeletal vibrations of benzene ring [39], while that at around 1035cm−1 is for CS vibration tethered on the benzene ring. Moreover, bands at 1220cm−1 and 1174cm−1 are respectively associated with the asymmetric and symmetric stretching signals of the OSO double bonds of a sulfonic group [31,34,40]. These observations demonstrate the successful incorporation of sulfonic groups onto the copolymer network. DVB and sodium p-styrene sulfonate showed CC double bond stretching vibration peak at about 1630cm−1 originated from the side chains on the benzene ring (Fig. S4). Such vibration peak disappeared in the copolymer product H-PDVB-SO3Na after washing, suggesting that rare of these monomers remained. The pore structure of H-PDVB-SO3H is investigated by N2 adsorption experiment. Fig. 2 shows the corresponding N2 adsorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves. H-PDVB-SO3H exhibits a typical type-IV isotherm with a clear H1-type hysteresis loop in the relative pressure P/P0 ranging from 0.8 to 0.9 (Fig. 2A, curve a), index of the formation of mesoporous structure [41]. A relatively wide pore size distribution is observed over H-PDVB-SO3H, and the most probable pore size locates at 13.9nm (Fig. 2B, curve a). As shown in Table 1 , H-PDVB-SO3H has the BET surface area of 380m2 g−1, large average pore size of 7.1nm and total pore volume of 0.67cm3 g−1. Fig. 3 and Fig. S5 show the morphology of H-PDVB-SO3H by the different scales of SEM images. Fresh copolymer material displays loose spongy structure composed of a large number of nanoparticles, which are closely interacted with each other and packed into large aggregations. The sulfur content in H-PDVB-SO3H is 2.5mmolg−1 from elemental analysis, lower than the one in the raw material (Table S1), which arises from the different polymerization properties of the two monomers. Correspondingly, its acid amount measured by acid-base titration is 2.36mmolg−1 [33]. The pyridine adsorption IR spectrum further reveals the presence of highly populated Brønsted acid sites with only slight Lewis acid sites on the surface of H-PDVB-SO3H [42] (Fig. S6). 3.2 Influence of reaction conditions on the Beckmann rearrangement catalyzed by H-PDVB-SO3H The sulfonic acid group-functionalized polymer H-PDVB-SO3H is tested as the catalyst for the Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime. ε-Caprolactam is the major product of this rearrangement reaction, and cyclohexanone is the by-product due to the deoximation of cyclohexanone oxime. The reaction conditions are optimized by systematically exploring the influence of various reaction parameters, including catalyst amount, reaction temperature and time, and solvent type and amount. Table 2 lists the influence of solvents, including benzonitrile (PhCN), dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), dimethylformamide (DMF), chlorobenzene (PhCl), toluene (PhMe), acetonitrile (MeCN), ethanol (EtOH) and dichloroethane (DCE). The polymer catalyst H-PDVB-SO3H is insoluble in all these solvents, fabricating a liquid–solid heterogeneous catalytic system. The results show that PhCN is the most efficient solvent, giving the highest conversion 100% and selectivity to ε-caprolactam 75% (Entry 1), whereas other solvents deliver low activity or even scarce production of ε-caprolactam. The result can be explained by the suitable polarity and basicity of PhCN, which is helpful in balancing the competitive adsorption of the solvent molecule with the basic substrate ketoxime, and the followed desorption of the basic amide produced on acidic sites [25,27,43]. Poor activity is observed by using DMSO and DMF with high polarity and basicity (Entries 2 and 3). Such type solvents probably poison the active acid sites, decreasing the activation of ketoxime on the active sites and therefore hindering the catalytic cycle [24,25]. The inferior performance of DMF than DMSO is due to the lower dielectric constant and the polarity of the former. PhCl with medium polar strength displays a low catalytic activity for this reaction (Entry 4), because the polar solvent molecule can stabilize the reaction intermediates such as N-protonated oxime [24]. PhMe gives both low conversion of 10% and low selectivity of 6.5%, and DCE is almost inactive (Entries 5 and 8), implying that nonpolar solvents like PhMe and DCE are not suitable for this reaction. MeCN is a well-known effective solvent for Lewis acid ZnCl2-cocatalyzed Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime (Entry 6) [20,28,44]. However, the low conversion of 6.7% and selectivity of 4% is observed in this cocatalyst-free system due to the low boiling point of MeCN (82°C) [29]. Besides, no product is detected by using protonic solvent EtOH (Entry 7), in good accordance with the previous report that the reaction did not proceed in polar protic solvents [45]. Successively, other reaction conditions are investigated by using PhCN as the solvent (Fig. 4 ). With the increase of PhCN amount, the conversion and selectivity first increases and then decreases, giving the highest activity by using 5mL solvent (Fig. 4A). The effect of catalyst amount is investigated from 0 to 0.125g (Fig. 4B). The conversion continuously increases to the maximum value at 0.1g catalyst and keeps constant with further enhancement of catalyst amount. The reaction temperature varies from 70 to 150°C, giving the maximum activity at 130°C (Fig. 4C). Fig. 4D depicts the influence of reaction time. The reaction catalyzed by H-PDVB-SO3H takes place so quickly, giving 78% conversion and 67.7% selectivity within a very short time of 0.5h, and the highest activity is observed within a short reaction time of 1h. Overall the optimized conditions are 1.0 mmol cyclohexanone oxime, 0.1g catalyst, 5mL PhCN, 130°C and 1h. 3.3 Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime over various catalysts Under above optimized reaction condition, we compare catalytic performances of H-PDVB-SO3H and various control samples. Catalytic results with corresponding textural properties of these catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The reaction does not proceed in the absence of a catalyst (Entry 1) [29]. The neat polymer PDVB is from polymerization of DVB and the copolymer P(DVB-ST) is obtained by copolymerization of DVB and styrene (ST). Both of them have large surface areas, but cannot catalyze this reaction due to the lack of acidic sites (Entries 2 and 4). In clear contrast, the in situ functionalized sulfonic copolymer catalyst H-PDVB-SO3H exhibits a perfect conversion of 100% with relatively high selectivity of 75% at a short reaction time of 1h (Entry 3). The major by-product is cyclohexanone generated from the hydrolysis of cyclohexanone oxime, while other trace amount by-products include cyclohexen-1-one, nitriles and dimers [9,25]. For comparison, the analogue copolymer solid acid P(DVB-ST)SO3H prepared by post-sulfonation of P(DVB-ST) presents a high conversion of 98.2% but a low selectivity of 57.3% (Entry 5). The reason may be attributable to the collapse of the pore structure during the post-sulfonation process. Also, commercial Amberlyst-15 shows the low conversion of 40.7% and selectivity of 57.7% (Entry 6). On the other hand, sulfonic acid-modified mesoporous silica SBA-15-SO3H demonstrates low conversion of 66.3% and selectivity of 73.4% (Entry 7), though it possesses similar sulfur content and large surface area as H-PDVB-SO3H. This phenomenon implies that the organic polymeric framework benefits higher activity for this reaction than the inorganic network. Additionally, even the homogeneous catalyst H2SO4 exhibits much lower conversion of 71.5% and selectivity of 40.8% than our heterogeneous H-PDVB-SO3H under the similar reaction conditions. All these control experiments reveal the advantage of the present acidic copolymer catalyst H-PDVB-SO3H for the Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime. The corresponding N2 adsorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves for the control solid catalysts are shown in Fig. S7. 3.4 Beckmann rearrangements of various substrates To explore the generality and scope of the Beckmann rearrangement catalyzed by H-PDVB-SO3H, representative oximes are examined as substrates, with the results summarized in Table 3 . It is gratifying to observe that not only aromatic oximes (Entries 1–5) but also the cycloalkanone oxime (Entry 6) are efficiently rearranged to the corresponding amides. All the substrates are completely converted, offering good to excellent selectivity to corresponding amide products. Their main by-products are the corresponding ketones and only trace amounts of dimeric oximes are observed. The results demonstrate that excellent catalytic activity is obtained with aromatic ketoximes (Entries 1–5) in this catalytic system. Electron withdrawing substituent like Cl (Entry 3) attached to the ketoxime favors high selectivity in the Beckmann rearrangement while electron donating substituents like OCH3 and O2N (Entries 2 and 5) retard the rearrangement, giving slightly lower selectivities [46]. When cyclopentanone oxime is used as the substrate, the target product δ-valerolactam exhibits moderate yield at the same reaction conditions (Entry 6), similar to the reaction by using cyclohexanone oxime. The above rearrangement over different substrates implies that the obtained H-PDVB-SO3H is able to convert various ketoximes to the corresponding amides within short reaction time of 1h, exhibiting well substrate compatibility. Comparatively study of the catalytic activity in Beckmann rearrangements of various substrates is given in Table S2. 3.5 Recycling of catalyst H-PDVB-SO3H for the Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime The catalyst H-PDVB-SO3H can be easily recovered by centrifugal treatment from the reacted mixture and reused in the next recycling run. However, if without the regeneration, significant decline of the conversion (∼20%) is observed over the reused catalyst, though the selectivity varies slightly. It is noticeable that well reusability can be obtained by treating the recovered catalyst with diluted H2SO4. As shown in Fig. 5 A, rare decrease of the conversion and selectivity happens during the five-run test through such a simple regeneration, similar to the behavior of previous polymeric solid acid FDU-14-SO3H in Beckmann rearrangement [31]. Recyclable performance of commercial Amberlyst-15 is investigated in parallel with similar regeneration treatment of the recovered catalyst by diluted H2SO4 within each two-run interval. The conversion drops rapidly at the 2nd run, and then gradually decreases in the following runs. The deactivation of Amberlyst-15 is attributable to the collapse of its framework that causes the loss of acid sites, thus Amberlyst-15 cannot be effectively regenerated by simply washing with diluted H2SO4. The above results indicate that H-PDVB-SO3H exhibit not only higher activity but also better reusability than Amberlyst-15. In order to further understand catalytic recyclability of H-PDVB-SO3H, the FT-IR spectra and elemental analysis are performed on the recovered catalyst with or without regeneration. The recovered catalysts, no matter of the regeneration, all possess the characteristic peaks for the polymeric skeleton (Fig. 1B, curve b and c). For example, the signals at 1600cm−1 and 1449cm−1 are assigned to CC skeletal vibrations of benzene ring [39]. The band at 1035cm−1 is derived from CS vibration. Bands at 1220cm−1 and 1174cm−1 are respectively attributed to νas(SO2) and νs(SO2) in the sulfonic group [31,34,40]. N2 adsorption isotherm of recovered H-PDVB-SO3H is also type-IV with a hysteresis loop in the relatively low partial pressure range of P/P0 =0.7–0.9 (Fig. 2A, curve b), giving the surface area of 270m2 g−1 and total pore volume of 0.5cm3 g−1, which is only slightly lower than the fresh one. Similar SEM images are observed over the recovered H-PDVB-SO3H (Fig. 3C and D). Such phenomena suggest that the polymeric structure of H-PDVB-SO3H is well retained during the recycling process. Nevertheless, a clear new band at 1658 cm−1 is observed on the recovered H-PDVB-SO3H sample without regeneration (Fig. 1B, curve b). This band is for the CO stretching vibration of ε-caprolactam, implying the significant adsorption of the basic organic compound on the solid acid catalyst. Elemental analysis of this recovered sample indicates the increase of C wt.% (68.05 wt.%) and N wt.% (5.44 wt.%) content compared with fresh catalyst (C 65.09 wt.%; N 0.31 wt.%), confirming the above speculation. It is owing to such adsorption that the basic organic compound covers and contaminates the acid sites of the solid acid catalyst, and ultimately leads to the decline of the activity [47]. After washing with diluted H2SO4, the recovered H-PDVB-SO3H after the fifth run demonstrates similar IR spectra as the fresh catalyst, which suggests resuming of the base-contaminated acid sites. However, the weak CO stretching vibration at 1658cm−1 indicates that the strong interaction between the acidic SO3H and the basic organic compound (amide product and/or oxime substrate) makes the regeneration treatment unable to totally remove the irreversible chemical interaction [28,47]. Additionally, the regenerated H-PDVB-SO3H (after the fifth reaction) shows increased C wt.% (71.13 wt.%) and N wt.% (2.7 wt.%) content compared with fresh catalyst (C 65.09 wt.%; N 0.31 wt.%), further revealing the insufficient remove of the adsorbed organic species. Therefore, the slight decrease of the conversion is still observed over the regenerated catalyst H-PDVB-SO3H. Despite this imperfection, the detailed investigations on the recyclability of the solid acid copolymer H-PDVB-SO3H still suggest a significant progress in catalyst stability and activity for this difficult reaction. 3.6 Discussion on catalytic performance of H-PDVB-SO3H by further comparisons As demonstrated above, the in situ sulfonated co-polymeric solid acid catalyst H-PDVB-SO3H presents high activity, well substrate compatibility and recyclability in the Beckmann rearrangement. The yield over H-PDVB-SO3H is higher than that over the post-sulfonated copolymer (P(DVB-ST)SO3H), commercial solid acid resin Amberlyst-15, organo-functionalized mesoporous silica acid SBA-15-SO3H and traditional liquid acid H2SO4 (Table 1). The high activity of H-PDVB-SO3H can be assigned to the large surface area, high concentration of acid sites and organic framework, all of which promote the accessibility of the substrate to the acid sites. The in situ incorporation of sulfonic group avoids the collapse of meso-structure that may occur in a post-sulfonation process, benefiting the preservation of abundant mesopores. In order to further understand the catalytic behavior of H-PDVB-SO3H, we compare its activity with various other catalysts reported previously (Table S1). Compared to previous post-sufonated polymeric solid acids for rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime, H-PDVB-SO3H exhibits comparable yield and similar recycling performance, but requires much shorter reaction time, revealing the advantage of in situ incorporating the sulfonic group. Several inorganic solid acids showed well reusability but their yields were inferior than H-PDVB-SO3H. In addition, the rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime or some other substrates over these inorganic catalysts usually required much longer reaction time or high reaction temperature. IL-derived heteropolyacid (HPA) catalyst [MIMPS]3PW12O40 gave high activities over various substrates but only in the presence of co-catalyst of ZnCl2, and a drastic decrease of activity was observed over the recovered [MIMPS]3PW12O40 (in the third run, 53% of its original activity was retained even added with fresh ZnCl2 for each recycling run) [28]. Another IL-HPA hybrid material [DPySO3H]1.5PW was proved to be an effective and recyclable catalyst for Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime in the absence of a cocatalyst [29], but a gradual decrease of activity was observed (in the third run, 80% of its original activity was retained). These additional comparisons indicate that the in situ sulfonated co-polymeric catalyst H-PDVB-SO3H is a green, efficient, and steadily recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for Beckmann rearrangement. 4 Conclusion Sulfonic copolymer solid acid H-PDVB-SO3H is prepared through one-step copolymerization of DVB with sodium p-styrene sulfonate under solvothermal conditions, followed with ion-exchange to convert into proton form. Such non-post-sulfonated copolymer is applied as the heterogeneous catalyst for liquid-phase Beckmann rearrangements for the first time. High conversion and selectivity are observed for the rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime and various other ketoximes within a short reaction time of 1h, showing high efficiency and well substrate compatibility. The catalyst also demonstrates superior reusability, displaying a considerably high activity even after five recycling runs in the rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime. Thus, H-PDVB-SO3H is considered to be one promising candidate for liquid-phase Beckmann rearrangements. coredata.dc:description: Exploring environmentally friendly, efficient and recyclable heterogeneous catalysts for low-temperature liquid-phase organic reactions are important for the development of green and sustainable processes. In this work, we applied an in situ sulfonated polymeric solid acid H-PDVB-SO3H for catalyzing liquid-phase Beckmann rearrangements for the first time, with post-sulfonated sample and other various counterparts as control catalysts. H-PDVB-SO3H was prepared by copolymerization of divinylbenzene with sodium p-styrene sulfonate under solvothermal condition, followed by ion-exchanging to convert the polymer into proton form. It possessed a large surface area, plenty of mesopores and high sulfur content, and exhibited the high yield to ε-caprolactam (75%) with quite steady reusability in the heterogeneous Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime. The catalyst also showed good substrate compatibility with such a high reaction rate that the reaction time was as short as 1h. No any co-catalysts or metals were used in the catalytic system, making the catalyst an environmentally friendly and efficient candidate for Beckmann rearrangements.
coredata.dc:title: In situ functionalized sulfonic copolymer toward recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for efficient Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime
